今天，“华盛顿邮报”记者里德·阿尔贝戈蒂(Reed Albergoti)和德鲁·哈威尔(Drew Harwell)报道了苹果和谷歌在冠状病毒暴露通知项目上的联合努力，这是我在“华盛顿邮报”看到的最糟糕的报道。这是如此可怕的糟糕，事实上是错误的，而且在 -  - 中是片面的，它应该被收回。
从标题开始：“苹果和谷歌正在建立一个病毒跟踪系统。卫生官员说，这几乎毫无用处。“。这不是一个“病毒跟踪系统”，“华盛顿邮报”采访的卫生官员不知道他们在说什么。
但随着科技巨头披露了更多细节，官员们现在表示，该软件将用处不大。由于这些公司制定的严格规定，如果智能手机用户可能接触到感染者，系统会通知他们，但不会与卫生官员分享任何数据，也不会透露会面地点。
当人们可能接触到感染者时通知他们，对我来说听起来很有用。诚然，苹果和谷歌的系统在设计上并不跟踪位置。的确，位置信息可能会对卫生官员有用。但是，即使没有附加位置数据，曝光通知本身也是有用的。
苹果和谷歌项目的要点是，它试图在隐私和跟踪潜在暴露的有用性之间取得平衡。它就在这个项目的名字里：“保护隐私--联系方式追踪”(Privacy-Protected Contact Tracing)。“华盛顿邮报”这篇报道的消息来源似乎想要一个完全不考虑隐私的系统。我希望这是夸大其词。
但苹果和谷歌拒绝了，他们辩称，让这些应用程序收集位置数据或放松其他智能手机规则将破坏人们的隐私。两家公司还担心，放松对应用程序蓝牙使用的限制会耗尽手机电池寿命，这可能会激怒客户。这种不屈不挠的立场导致一些卫生当局放弃了建立一个功能齐全的接触者追踪应用程序的希望。
“坚定不移的立场”是对苹果和谷歌希望不“破坏人们的隐私”或“耗尽手机电池寿命”的相当苛刻的描述。这不是“坚定不移的姿态”。这是设计人们将实际安装和使用的系统的赌注。想象一下，试图向公众推销的系统会破坏他们的隐私或不适当地耗尽他们的手机电池 - ，更不用说一个兼具这两种功能的系统了。
但康奈尔大学(Cornell University)信息学教授兼数字生活倡议(Digital Life Initiative)主任海伦·尼森鲍姆(Helen Nissenbaum)称，苹果和谷歌利用隐私为拒绝允许公共卫生官员获取手机技术进行辩护，是一个“华丽的烟幕”。她说，这两家公司多年来一直容忍大量收集人们的数据，但现在却阻止将其用于“对公众健康至关重要”的目的，这是浪费时间的。
她说：“如果是在谷歌和苹果之间拥有数据，我更希望我的医生和公共卫生当局拥有关于我健康状况的数据。”“至少他们受到法律的约束。”
尼森鲍姆显然完全不知道这个系统是如何设计的，尽管苹果和谷歌已经发布了一份7页的简明常见问题解答，用简单易懂的术语对其进行了解释。很明显，无论是“华盛顿邮报”的记者还是尼森鲍姆的记者都没有读过这个常见问题，或者即使他们读了，也不理解它。(或者故意忽略它。)。
谷歌和苹果将不会“拥有数据”。它完全且仅存储在每个用户自己的设备上。我们，用户，将拥有数据，我们，用户，可以与我们的医生共享这些数据。
那么“至少他们受到法律的约束”到底是怎么进入这个故事的呢？尼森鲍姆认为苹果和谷歌不受法律约束？这对两家公司的法律合规部门来说都是新闻，我估计他们很快就会被解雇。
苹果-谷歌系统使用人们智能手机中的短距离蓝牙天线来记录两个人在短时间内接触的时间，但不是在接触发生的地方。如果其中一个人的非冠状病毒感染检测呈阳性，就会发出警报，但这些信息不会与公共卫生官员或接触者追踪小组共享。
这几乎是一种准确的描述，如果你眯着眼睛， -  - ，但“华盛顿邮报”遗漏了什么是必不可少的。这些信息不会自动与卫生官员共享，但如果你选择进入系统，并收到一条通知，表明你可能与检测呈阳性的人有过联系，那么你就可以与你的医生分享这些信息。只有医生和注册的卫生官员才能确认该系统中的用户的冠状病毒 - 检测呈阳性，否则，这将是恶作剧者的开放季节。
围绕病毒跟踪应用程序的紧张关系反映了科技巨头与州和地方卫生官员之间的重大权力失衡，这些官员辩称，苹果和谷歌的技术决定削弱了他们对全球卫生紧急情况的反应。它还突显了科技巨头对数十亿部智能手机如何工作施加不受约束的控制的能力。
这简直是胡说八道。智能手机符合世界各地名副其实的堆积如山的法规和法律。如果你使用iphone，只需查看设置、→常规、→法律法规。
“他们在行使主权。这简直太疯狂了，“美国经济自由项目(American EconomicLiberties Project)的研究主管马特·斯托勒(MattStoller)说。该项目是华盛顿一家致力于减少垄断力量的智囊团。他补充说，苹果和谷歌已经“为全世界做出了决定”，“这不是由公众来决定的。”…。你有一个私人政府在你的社会上做出选择，而不是民主政府能够做出这些选择。“。
这句话太疯狂了。再说一遍，这个叫斯托勒的家伙显然不知道他在说什么。苹果和谷歌决定他们的操作系统如何工作，遵守世界各地的所有现有法律，并不是在“行使主权”。这里没有人声称苹果或谷歌在做任何事情，即使是含糊的非法行为。他们不是在循规蹈矩，也不是在利用任何形式的漏洞。
如果苹果和谷歌做了斯托勒和尼森鲍姆似乎希望他们做的事情， - 追踪你接触的每个人的位置数据，并自动向政府卫生官员报告这些数据，他们几乎肯定会违反世界各地的各种法律。欧洲善意但过于热心的gdpr法律 - 88页pdf - 引述其序言中的话说：“自然人应该控制他们自己的个人数据。”这正是苹果和谷歌的System - 的意义所在，似乎与这篇文章中每个消息来源认为苹果和谷歌应该做的事情完全相反。
此外，关于斯托勒对民主的倡导，祝你能找到公众对这个系统的支持，这个系统将手机变成监控设备，完全可以自动向政府报告任何事情，更不用说像我们接触过的人和我们去过的地方这样敏感的东西了。我承认，人们可以证明，政府卫生官员可以自动从我们的手机中获取此类数据的系统，在追踪冠状病毒感染方面可能是有用的。但是试着让它得到大众的支持。我见过的任何人都没有提出这样的系统对于使用手机来帮助追踪联系人是必要的。
(A)对智能手机可能被用来通过跟踪和数据收集来滥用个人隐私的非常复杂的方式进行了长期而认真的思考的人，与(B)令人钦佩地试图追踪冠状病毒的公共卫生官员之间没有太多重叠。这篇报道没有引用这两个群体交汇处的少数人的话。
这些公司争辩说，限制应用程序使用的数据可能会提高它们的采用率，因为人们可能不信任或不使用记录他们位置的应用程序，以便公共卫生当局以后使用。
但包括苹果和谷歌总部在内的美国一些地区表示，这些限制实际上已经让这些应用程序变得毫无用处。
这些应用都还没有发布，因为iOS和Android的API还没有发布。
今天的接触追踪者使用电话和采访来追踪人们的行动，并且几乎完全依赖于人们的记忆。一些官员认为，人们手机每分钟记录的位置记录可以提供一种更精确、更自动化的方式来跟踪新的疫情，从而减轻这一负担。
在其他情况下，上述段落还会通过嗅探测试吗？“一些官员” - 未透露姓名、来源不明的 - 辩称，政府应该享受“人们手机记录的每分钟位置日志”，而这在新闻报道中是零阻力的。对这一论点没有丝毫抵触，它描述的场景正是潜在的隐私惨败的定义。
加州大学旧金山分校(University of California，San Francisco)医学助理教授迈克·里德(MikeReid)说：“这些应用程序的局限性很大。”他领导了该州培训接触追踪人员的工作。“我不认为对大多数人来说，他们扮演着重要的角色。”
他说，接触追踪器将使用Salesforce和埃森哲制造的软件来帮助通过电话联系患者，并接受如何保护患者敏感信息的培训。
“我们不遗余力地尽量减少从人们那里获取的数据量，并征得我们在电话中交谈的人的同意。他说：“我们不遗余力地确保有强有力的技术控制，以确保我们平台的匿名化，你能对这些大型科技公司说同样的话吗？我不确定。“。
是的，所以如果苹果和谷歌将数据最小化，只将其存储在设备本身，而不是收集到他们的服务器上，那会更好。他们应该详细解释他们的系统是如何自始至终保护隐私和确保匿名性的。
还有 - ！ - 我们现在有个人将在加州培训接触追踪人员，他自愿公开表示，Salesforce和埃森哲在合同跟踪隐私保护方面更值得信任(有详细的位置数据！)。而不是苹果/谷歌的提议。该死的。
联邦贸易委员会(FederalTrade Commission)前首席技术专家阿什坎·索尔塔尼(Ashkan Soltani)表示，苹果和谷歌的做法，“我们过度补偿了隐私，但仍然制造了其他风险，却没有解决问题。”“如果它是一家我信任的健康机构，对数据的使用有法律保护，而且我知道它是由专职的安全团队运营的，我个人会更放心。”
看到阿什坎·索尔塔尼(Ashkan Soltani)在所有人中说“我们过度补偿了隐私”，这是理所当然的令人惊讶的事情。
汤姆·弗里登(Tom Frieden)是疾病控制和预防中心(Centers For DiseaseControl And Prevention)的前主任，现在与健康组织Vital Strategy合作。他说，苹果和谷歌提出的近距离追踪系统“在很大程度上分散了人们的注意力”。
弗里登在周三的一次采访中说：“在充分尊重隐私的情况下，它的可行性和可行性受到了非常严重的质疑，它把实际需要发生的事情搅乱了。”“这是一种在没有太多理解的情况下完成的方法，而且有很多言过其实的地方。”
以下是苹果和谷歌的联合声明。这两家公司到底承诺了什么？是不是一群没有参与其中，没有读过说明书，甚至不理解提案的白痴跳到了承诺过头的结论上？好的。但这怎么会是苹果或谷歌的错呢？
他说，近距离追踪系统是“一个明亮的闪闪发光的物体，但现在他们没有做任何事情来阻止这场大流行。”
也许是因为他们还没他妈的出局？哈利路亚，我靠， - ，泰诺在哪里？
note_en:
A Washington Post story today  on Apple and Google’s joint effort on COVID-19 exposure notification project, from reporters Reed Albergotti and Drew Harwell, is the worst story I’ve seen in the Post in memory. It’s so atrociously bad — factually wrong and one-sided in opinion — that it should be retracted.
 Start with the headline: “ Apple and Google Are Building a Virus-Tracking System. Health Officials Say It Will Be Practically Useless.” It’s not a “virus-tracking system”, and the health officials the Post talked to don’t know what they’re talking about.
 But as the tech giants have revealed more details, officials nowsay the software will be of little use. Due to strict rulesimposed by the companies, the system will notify smartphone usersif they’ve potentially come into contact with an infected person,but it won’t share any data with health officials or reveal wherethose meetings took place.
 Notifying people when they’ve potentially come into contact with an infected person sounds useful to me. It’s true that by design, Apple and Google’s system does not track location. It’s true that location information would be potentially useful to health officials. But the exposure notifications alone are inherently useful, even without location data attached.
 The gist of Apple and Google’s project is that it attempts to balance privacy with the usefulness of tracking potential exposure. It’s right there in the name of the project: “ Privacy-Protecting Contact Tracing”. The Post’s sources for this story seemingly want a system with no regard for privacy at all. I wish that were an exaggeration.
 But Apple and Google have refused, arguing that letting the appscollect location data or loosening other smartphone rules wouldundermine people’s privacy. The companies are also concerned thateasing the restrictions around apps’ Bluetooth use would drainphone battery life, which could irritate customers. That unbendingstance has led some health authorities to abandon hopes ofbuilding a fully functioning contact-tracing app.
 “Unbending stance” is a rather harsh description of Apple and Google’s desire not to “undermine people’s privacy” or “drain phone battery life”. This isn’t an “unbending stance”. It’s table stakes for designing a system that people will actually install and use. Imagine trying to sell the public on a system that undermines their privacy or unduly drains their phone batteries — let alone a system that does both.
 But Helen Nissenbaum, a professor of information science anddirector of the  Digital Life Initiative at CornellUniversity, called Apple and Google’s use of privacy to defendtheir refusal to allow public health officials access tosmartphone technology a “flamboyant smokescreen.” She said it wasironic that the two companies had for years tolerated the masscollection of people’s data but were now preventing its use for apurpose that is “critical to public health.”
 “If it’s between Google and Apple having the data, I would farprefer my physician and the public health authorities to have thedata about my health status,” she said. “At least they’reconstrained by laws.”
 Nissenbaum obviously has no idea whatsoever how this system is designed to work, despite the fact that Apple and Google have published  a succinct 7-page FAQ that explains it in simple, easy-to-understand terms. It seems clear that neither the reporters from the Post nor Nissenbaum have read that FAQ, or if they did, don’t understand it. (Or willfully ignored it.)
 Google and Apple will not “have the data”. It is stored entirely and only on each user’s own device. We, the users, will have the data, and we, the users, can share that data with our doctors.
 And how in the world did “At least they’re constrained by laws” make it into this story? Nissenbaum believes Apple and Google are  not constrained by laws? That will be news to both companies’ legal compliance departments, who I presume will soon be laid off.
 The Apple-Google system uses the short-range Bluetooth antennas inpeople’s smartphones to log when two people come into contact fora short period of time, but not where that contact took place. Analert is sent if one of the people tests positive for acoronavirus infection, but that information is not shared withpublic health officials or contact-tracing teams.
 That’s close to an accurate description — sort of, if you squint your eyes — but what the Post omits is essential. The information is not shared  automatically with health officials, but if you opt into the system and get a notification that you’ve potentially been in contact with someone who has tested positive, you can then share that information with your doctor. Only doctors and registered health officials can confirm that a user in this system has tested positive for COVID-19 — otherwise, it would be open season for pranksters.
 The tension over virus-tracking apps reflects a major powerimbalance between the tech giants and state and local healthofficials, who argue that Apple and Google’s technical decisionshave undermined their response to a global health emergency. Italso highlights the tech giants’ ability to exert unfetteredcontrol over how billions of smartphones work.
 This is nonsense. Smartphones comply with a veritable mountain of regulations and laws around the world. If you use an iPhone just look in Settings → General → Legal & Regulatory.
 “They are exercising sovereign power. It’s just crazy,” said MattStoller, the director of research at the American EconomicLiberties Project, a Washington think tank devoted to reducing thepower of monopolies. Apple and Google have “decided for the wholeworld,” he added, “that it’s not a decision for the public tomake. … You have a private government that is making choices overyour society instead of democratic governments being able to makethose choices.”
 This quote is what’s crazy. Again, this guy Stoller clearly has no idea what he’s talking about. Apple and Google deciding how their operating systems work, in compliance will all existing laws, all around the world, is not “exercising sovereign power”. No one here is alleging that Apple or Google are doing anything even vaguely illegal. They’re not toeing some sort of line, they’re not taking advantage of any sort of loopholes.
 And if Apple and Google did what Stoller and Nissenbaum seem to want them to do — track location data of every person you’re in contact with and report that data automatically to government health officials, they almost certainly  would be breaking all sorts of laws around the world. The whole point of Europe’s well-intentioned but overzealous GDPR law —  88 dense pages in PDF — is, quoting from its preamble, “Natural persons should have control of their own personal data.” That’s exactly the point of Apple and Google’s system — and seemingly exactly the opposite of what every source in this Post story thinks Apple and Google should do.
 Also, regarding Stoller’s advocacy for democracy, good luck finding public support for a system that turns phones into surveillance devices that report anything at all automatically to the government, let alone something as sensitive as who we’ve been in contact with and where we’ve been. I’ll grant that one can make a case that a system where government health officials have access to such data from our phones, automatically, could be useful in tracking COVID-19 infections. But try getting popular support for it. And no one I’ve seen has made the case that such a system is  necessary for using phones in the aid of contact tracing.
 There is not much overlap between (a) people who have thought long and hard about the very complicated ways smartphones can be used to abuse personal privacy with tracking and data collection; and (b) public health officials admirably trying to track COVID-19. None of the few people in the intersection of those two groups were quoted in this story.
 The companies have argued that limiting the data the apps usecould bolster their adoption rate, because people may not trust oruse an app that logs their location for later use by public healthauthorities.
  But some parts of the U.S., including Apple and Google’s homestate, say the restrictions have rendered the apps effectivelyuseless.
 None of these apps are out yet, because the APIs in iOS and Android aren’t out yet.
 Contact tracers today use phone calls and interviews to track people’s movements, and rely almost entirely on people’s memory. Minute-by-minute location logs recorded by people’s phones, some officials have argued, could ease that burden by providing a more precise and automated way to track new outbreaks.
 In what other context would the above paragraph pass the sniff test? “Some officials” — unnamed, unsourced — are arguing that the government should enjoy “minute-by-minute location logs recorded by people’s phones” and this is given  zero pushback in a news story. No pushback at all on this argument, describing a scenario that is the very definition of a potential privacy fiasco.
 “The limitations of those kind of apps are extensive,” said MikeReid, an assistant professor of medicine at University ofCalifornia, San Francisco, who’s leading the effort to traincontact tracers in the state. “I don’t think they have animportant role to play for most of the population.”
 The contact tracers, he said, will be using software made bySalesforce and Accenture to help reach patients by phone and aretrained on how to protect sensitive patient information.
 “We go to pains to minimize the amount of data we take from peopleand we ask consent from people we’re talking to on the phone. Wego to considerable lengths to ensure there are strong technicalcontrols to ensure the anonymization of our platforms,” he said.“Can you say the same thing about these big tech companies? I’mnot sure.”
 Yeah, so it would be better if Apple and Google minimized the data and stored it only on the devices themselves, rather than collecting it on their servers. And they should explain in detail how their system protects privacy and ensures anonymity from start to finish.
  Also — also! — we now have someone who will be training contact tracers in California, who voluntarily went on the record that Salesforce and Accenture are more worthy of trust for contract-tracing privacy protection (with detailed location data!) than the Apple/Google proposal. Goddamn.
 With the Apple and Google approach, “we’ve overcompensated forprivacy and still created other risks and not solved the problem,”said Ashkan Soltani, the former chief technologist of the FederalTrade Commission. “I’d personally be more comfortable if it were ahealth agency that I trusted and there were legal protections inplace over the use of the data and I knew it was operated by adedicated security team.”
 It is legit amazing to see  Ashkan Soltani, of all people, say “we’ve overcompensated for privacy.”
 Tom Frieden, the former director of the Centers for DiseaseControl and Prevention now working with the health organizationVital Strategies, said the proximity-tracing system as proposed byApple and Google has “been largely a distraction.”
 “There are very serious questions about its feasibility and itsability to be done with adequate respect for privacy, and it hasmuddied the water for what actually needs to happen,” Frieden saidin an interview Wednesday. “This was an approach that was donewith not much understanding and a lot of overpromising.”
 Here is Apple and Google’s joint announcement. What exactly did either company overpromise? Did a bunch of idiots who weren’t involved, didn’t read the specs, and don’t even understand the proposal jump to overpromise-y conclusions? Sure. But how is that Apple or Google’s fault?
 The proximity-tracing systems are “a bright shiny object,” hesaid, “but right now they’re doing nothing to stop the pandemic.”
 Maybe because they’re  not fucking out yet? Hallelujah, holy shit — where’s the Tylenol?

(CNN)本周在网上参加先修课程考试的高中生下个月可能会因为技术故障再次参加考试。
由于冠状病毒大流行已经关闭了学校，学生们今年被迫在网上参加他们的大学学分考试，但有几名学生报告说，他们在提交限时考试的答案时遇到了问题。
负责AP考试的大学理事会告诉CNN，他们意识到一些学生在完成考试时遇到了困难。
周三，大学理事会表示，他们仔细调查了一下，发现过时的浏览器是造成这些挑战的主要原因，他们在推特上写道。
在考试还剩45秒的时候，佛罗里达州杰克逊维尔的11年级学生玛吉·麦克劳克林(Maggie McLauchlin)按照大学理事会的指示，在上传考试答案时拍摄了一段似乎是黑屏的视频。
“我正在试着拍照，但那是黑色的，我只剩下45秒了，”麦琪泪流满面地说。它不工作了。
麦琪的母亲劳拉·麦克劳克林说，她的女儿和其他许多十几岁的孩子一样，几个月来一直在为她的AP考试而学习。重新测试的想法令人不安。
劳拉·麦克劳克林说，你只有48小时的时间要求重新测试。但与此同时，他们不会发送确认电子邮件，所以现在我们不知道她是否注册了重新测试。
她说，过时的浏览器不可能是她女儿周四在AP化学考试中出现技术问题的原因。
她(玛吉)做了一次考前试验，她登录参加了一次考试，并使用他们(大学理事会)的技术为她的模拟考试拍了一张照片并上传到网上，在这个过程中，一切都很正常，她说。因此，昨天当她参加考试时，她有充分的理由相信这个系统会起作用。
根据大学理事会的数据，在考试的前四天，学生们参加了164万次AP考试。该组织表示，在测试期间，至少有300万学生将参加考试。
大学理事会周五在给CNN的一份声明中表示，经过最初几天的测试，我们的数据显示，绝大多数学生成功完成了考试，只有不到1%的学生无法提交答案。我们和那些无法完成考试的学生一样深感失望--无论是因为技术问题还是其他原因。
每个测试的形式根据学生要测试的科目而有所不同。对于大多数考试，第一部分由多项选择题组成，第二部分包括几个自由回答的问题。
就2020年AP考试的在家考试而言，大学理事会的网站上说，每一次考试都是在全球范围内的特定时间进行的，有一到两个自由回答的问题。
所有的考试都是翻开书本，打开笔记，时间为45分钟。大学理事会要求学生在考试前30分钟登录。
根据大学理事会的网站，学生们将可以在他们可以访问的任何设备上考试-电脑、平板电脑或智能手机。他们将能够打印并上传他们的回复，或者手写回复并通过手机提交照片。
大学理事会在声明中表示，他们努力在6月份补考之前了解这些学生的独特情况。任何在考试中遇到问题的学生都可以重新考试。
根据大学理事会的一份声明，学生们不需要再支付费用来重新测试，但已经支付或不想重新测试并希望退款的学生需要与学校的AP协调员进行交谈。
福克斯告诉CNN，他报名参加了四次美联社测试，由于时差，他一直在凌晨3点和5点醒来。去参加考试。
在他参加的四次考试中，有两次因为技术故障而没有提交。
在他在推特上发布的一段视频中，他展示了他试图上传考试答案的不同方式，但每次都失败了。
@AP_Trevor我刚在凌晨3点和5点参加了两次AP考试，两次考试都没能处理我的图像，迫使我报名重考。以下是我试图提交最后一个答案的视频：pic.twitter.com/Yq0k7vm0ky。
--鲁本·富克斯(@rubenFuchs)2020年5月14日。
福克斯说，这除了让人沮丧之外，还让人非常不舒服。因为我以为测试的压力现在已经结束了。但现在我将不得不重新学习我的材料，为这次考试投入比所需更多的时间，这不是我的错。
福克斯说，他希望大学理事会能允许他根据照片拍摄时的时间戳提交他的旧答案。如果他们没有，他希望当他重新测试时，同样的错误不会再次发生。
Jamye Smith是密苏里州O&#39；Fallon的Zumwalt北堡高中的一名美联社美国历史教师。她告诉CNN，她的27名学生报名参加了考试。她说，到目前为止，她收到了三名学生的来信，他们因为各种错误而无法提交考试，这些错误都不是他们造成的。
史密斯说，她教授其他科目的同事也说，他们的学生也很难做到同样的事情。
她说：我意识到，对一些人来说，三个学生听起来可能不算什么，但对这三个人和我来说，这是一件非常重要的事情。他们几个月来一直很努力地学习，边工作，边运动，边上其他高级课程。
史密斯说，她同情她的学生们的沮丧和愤怒，并鼓励他们报名参加重新测试，尽管他们对最近的经历感到担忧。
她说：我提醒他们，他们付出了多少努力，他们学到了多少东西，我相信他们，不想让他们有任何遗憾。
史密斯说，学生的AP考试将再拖延几个星期，以重考结束，即使不是比第一次考试的压力更大，也和他们的第一次考试一样。

我不确定如何保护平台。或许可以及早与EFF这样值得信赖的透明组织合作，让他们定期公开审计平台，并表示，如果这一点发生变化，对平台的公开透明定期审计应该立即阻止它，用户应该立即认为它受到了损害，并停止使用它。

此外，平台必须盈利或承诺在不滥用用户或客人的情况下未来盈利。这可以是某家大型互联网广告公司提供的广告，也可以是作为平台一部分的广告公司提供的广告。没有太多的广告，所以博客被毁了，但可能在底部或顶部和底部都有广告，保留了属于博客作者的空间。此外，该公司可能永远不应该上市，因为我们已经看到，几家大公司或政府的参与如何让互联网(以及过去的表达形式)变得更糟，这两件事中任何一件事的参与程度都会侵蚀或完全摧毁它。

Nowadays especially it's nice to have things to read. New things, things from various sources and various voices, various minds talking about their thoughts and experiences, telling their stories, posting pictures and things that are relevant to them. A couple of years ago, maybe 8 or 10 so maybe longer than a lot of people will be able to remember, there were blogs on the internet. You could search around and they'd come up even in websearch, and you'd find yourself reading someone's blogs. Maybe it was chronicles of their life as they got a job teaching in Japan and how it was leaving American for the first time and all the new things there and skateboarding and meeting people and trying to meet girls, or a photographer working for a while in Minorca or some island off Spain when music hit a rock scene period and all the young people were dressing up in leather and tight jeans and going out dancing to dance rock and writing about his thoughts on where he fit into the scene as he was kind of older but not old, or a compilation of weird and unexplained science and gnostic wisdom, or the things some guy was making out of wood or electronics in his garage, or some Japanese girl who posted pictures of herself looking extremely pink and pneumatic and writing little things with them.
 Nowadays when everyone is on lockdown and there are days with nothing but spaces of time to pass, nights too, and you can make a hot tea or a coffee and sit down but when you look there's nothing to read. You can't access those unique voices writing about the things they care about, that are happening to them.
 The other day I searched for an hour and couldn't find even one. They used to be endless. You'd just click on one you knew on Blogger and either click Blogger's random blog button, or go to the sidebar of the blog you knew where they always had a list of blogs they liked, sometimes four or 5, sometimes 20 other blogs. And the same with Tumbler.
 Blogs used to exist because there were blogging platforms. But Blogger was shut down by Google years ago, and the blogs on there have been disappearing until now you just can't find really any, and they're not indexed in search anymore. Tumbler also was used by people to blog about their lives and interests, although there were also a lot of just pictures blogs, but it recently changed its policy and now permits no NSFW content, which compromised basically every blog that mentioned something not completely PG. All the old Tumbler blogs I had bookmarks for I can't even access anymore because they were deemed by Tumbler to have NSFW content. I think about how those people must feel after putting all that work into making such a special thing and then Tumbler just destroys it. And that's the end. There's no way to find blogs, and no one is writing them because there's no platform for them.
 But they would be the one thing I'd bring back to the internet if I could bring one thing back. They're the thing I miss the most and the most often. They were the most valuable thing on here, besides freer availability of news, free although low quality video content on YouTube, and I guess some kinds of social media. But blogs are something you can sit down and read and get really into to the point you forget where you even are, and think about how you want to try those things maybe in your life, or just enjoy their writing, and you can read deeper into them into past blog posts, and tune back in later and see what they've posted since the last things you read about them.
 When you search for blogs now on you see things like 'Top 100 Blogs.' 'How to Make a Successful Blog.' 'Most Powerful 50 Blogs.' But what you really want is 10,000 unsuccessful blogs. Web search now suggests ideas for your blogs to get views, shares, indexed, but what you really want is no ideas. It's almost impossible now to find a blog that's not on a focused theme because that's what search engines focus on and how websites profit. But you want the opposite, a blog that never tried to focus or even thought about it. There used to seem to be endless search results indexed by Google and the other search engines that were killed by Google. Maybe you'd see 40,000 results for your search. Now it says there are 40,000 but you only get 10 or 20 pages of results you can get to, all basically corporate and lame. You can't get to the 100th page anymore. It'd be nice even if someone built a crawler-indexer that you could use to search for everything including things that weren't popular or judged by algorithms to be 'relevant.' The problem with alternative engines like DuckDuckGo is they just use Google Search and don't crawl and index things in their own way. If they did they'd be fun and useful to use for reasons other than protection of privacy. Although some people say Google is becoming more and more useless to the point it won't be revived and may collapse for this reason although even if that were true we'd still have to suffer with it for years.
  A couple of notes, in case anyone is thinking of starting a new blogging platform:
 There's no point if you're not going to protect people, and that means their privacy. Nowadays people won't share content simply because they don't trust the internet to share content to it. You have to provide for them to be anonymous and protected forever, which means letting people create accounts easily with just an email or something similar, and log into them or recover their password throught the email if they lose their password, and never any locking them out because you noticed suspicious activity or anything bogus like that and making them provide personal details. That is abuse of trust and abuse of people. They have to be able to blog without thinking someone is going to bring it up and file it away forever and maybe they won't get a job because of it, or their tyrannical government will think they're an agitator and attack them or an adversary will use it for selective characger defamation sometime. They have to be able to abandon a blog, start a new one, blog there, abandon it, etc. Otherwise they won't feel free to write, so you may as well not say you're going to provide a blogging platform for people if you won't protect them.
 Privacy protection and the inability of this to be changed to be used maliciously must be baked in at the start. I doubt Larry and Sergei or even Gates would have created what they did the way they did if they knew what it would be used for. Those guys now can try to find other things to do with their lives now, or make up for it with charity, but their inventions are tools terribly used against people on such an extreme level. Anybody creating anything they think might someday become big should bake in at the start prevention against the possibility it could be used negatively when it becomes useful to powerful entities. I'm not sure the hosting servers could be based in the US because the US doesn't protect privacy or internet usage. I'm not sure where does. I read that Argentina has constitutional law that protect insternet expression, although that freedom is tempered by the prohibition of writing about their own government. Entitites that hate that Argentina has a protected free speech internet while the US and Canada and Europe don't protect human rights on the internet will say 'Well because of that Argentina is providing for terrorism and harming children, the two favorite claims of people who want to attack people or systems when those people or systems haven't done anything actually wrong and they need to raise alarm in their supporters. Of course, those acts are prohibited in Argentina, but speech and expression on their internet is not, including of those things, as far as I know. I mean, just the idea: 'illegal information.' 'Illegal speech.'
 I'm not sure how a platform could be protected. Perhaps by partnering early with a trusted, transparent organization like the EFF and having them publicly audit the platform on a regular basis and saying that if this is ever altered and public transparent regular audits of the platform stop it's users should immediately consider it compromised and stop using it.
 Also, you have to keep the content on the server of backed up forever, otherwise they won't feel their effort in blogging for years will be worthwhile if the platform will someday just erase it like Blogger and Tumbler did. Maybe the platform doesn't have a ton of money so it has to not save the images or videos, but at least the text should be maintained.
 Also, the platform must be profitable or promise future profit without abusing users or guests. This can simply be ads provided by one of the big internet ads companies or an ads company that's part of the platform. Not too many ads so the blogs are ruined, but maybe an ad at the bottom or perhaps the top and bottom, preserving the space that belongs to the blogger. Also the company probably should not ever go public, as we have seen how the involvement of a couple of big corporations or governments made the internet (and past forms of expression) worse, and that any degree of involvement of either of these two things will eat away or completely destroy it.
 Ie, a platform where people can securely and privately blog, where it can't be converted into a tool for abuse of people, and where freedom of privacy, thought, expression and discussion is maintained and there is no 'chilling effect on speech.'
